params.text:
Parallel corpora are essential to train high-quality and domain-oriented NMT systems. But, what are parallel corpora after all, where can one find them? 

There are a number of repositories and places where one may find parallel corpora. One starting point is a repository called OPUS. In OPUS one may find generic and domain-specific parallel corpora. Let's take a look. 

  • Go to the OPUS website at https://opus.nlpl.eu/ and use the language selector to choose a language combination of your interest. You will get a list of corpora along with some statistics about size and the corpora in different formats. You will also see a column called “sample”. Below the table, you have a list with brief explanations of the corpora and links to them. 

  • Pick 2 of the corpora available for your language combination and explore them by clicking on the “sample” column. Take a look at the sample (oh, parallel sentences!), and then go back and look for the corpus name in the list, read the info and, if you want to know a bit more, follow the link. 

  • After doing all this for both corpora, copy the following table in a piece of paper and fill it with your findings (spoiler, Domain is the trickiest info, you will need to be creative and provide a domain based on what you saw in the sample and the corpus description):
Corpus Name Size (sentences) Domain

Let's now discuss your results with your mates and answer these questions: 

  • Did you discover any in-domain corpus?
  • Did you inspect big, middle-sized or tiny corpora?
  • Any comments on what you saw on the samples?

params.text:
Finally, if you are working with MutNMT, let’s go a bit further depending on your MutNMT profile: 

For MutNMT experts: ​​if you found any of the OPUS corpora interesting and these do not contain more than 1.5 million sentences, you can upload them to MutNMT. To do so, you need to download the chosen corpus in TMX format (you will get a file ending in tmx.gz), uncompress it if your operating system does not do it for you, and upload it to MutNMT data section, filling in all required details (even Domain and that might be different from the one you picked previously in the exercise!) and choosing TMX as the desired format. The corpus will appear in Your Corpora list, where you will be able to share it so that other people can see in it the Public List. Now, you can see this corpus and their details on MutNMT and take a look at them using the option Preview under the three dots menu available for each corpus. 

For MutNMT beginners: some of the OPUS available corpora have been already added to MutNMT. Access MutNMT and take a look at the Public Corpora list. Take a look at their details (name, description, size, domain) and take a look at them using the option Preview under the three dots menu available for each corpus. 

This is a parallel corpus!
